Surface species on copper/zirconia catalysts: implications for methanol synthesis selectivity C. Schild, A. Wokaun* Physical Chemistry II, University of Bayreuth, P.O. Box 101251, D-8580 Bayreuth (F.R.G.) and A. Baiker Department of Industrial and Engineering Chemistry, Swiss Federal Institute of Technology, ETH Zentrum, CH-8092 Zurich (Switzerland) (Received April 10, 1990; revised June 11, 1990) Abstract Hydrogenation reactions of CO and COz over copper/zirconia catalysts obtained from an amorphous CuyoZrgo precursor, as well as catalysts prepared by coprecipitation and sequential precipitation of copper and zirconium hydroxides, were investigated by diffuse reflectance FTIR spectroscopy. Surface species and reaction products are compared with those on palladium/zirconia catalyst systems, for which results have been reported in Part I of this study. Two major pathways were identified from the observed correlations of surface species and gas phase products, (i) The rapid adsorption of COa followed by reduction yields surface formate, which is efficiently reduced to methane without further observable intermediates, (ii) The adsorption of CO in the presence of hydrogen yields Tr-bonded formaldehyde, which is reduced to methylate and finally methanol. These two reaction systems are connected, as COg and CO can be interconverted on the catalyst surface by the water-gas shift reaction. While the principal types of surface species are similar in Pd/ZrOg and Cu/ZrOa catalyst systems, there are large differences in the selectivities towards methane and methanol, respectively. Apparently the amorphous zirconia support mainly provides adsorption sites for the surface reaction intermediates. The activity of the metal and its interface, on the other hand, is the decisive factor in determining the principle hydrogenation product. Palladium is very active in reducing surface formate to methane; as a consequence of the continuous desorption of methane, COg is replenished on the surface by the water-gas shift reaction, and the product distribution is biased towards the principal COz hydrogenation product, i.e. methane. With copper, on the other hand, formate hydrogenation is less effective. In contrast, there is a favorable reaction pathway on copper in which adsorbed CO is reduced to methanol without C 0 bond cleavage. The reverse water-gas shift equilibrium is biased towards CO on the copper surface, and methanol can be obtained as the principle COg hydrogenation product. Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/90/$3.50 Elsevler Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 244 Introduction Mechanistic studies with supported copper as a catalyst for methanol synthesis have been the subject of various investigations, especially for the Cu/ZnO/AlaOa system. One of the basic questions concerning hydrogenation of COg/CO mixtures is whether carbon dioxide or carbon monoxide is the main source of carbon in the methanol product. Denise et al. [ 1 ] and Saussey and Lavalley [2] have obtained evidence for two different mechanisms for methanol production from carbon monoxide and carbon dioxide, depending on the feed gas composition. Chinchen et al. [3] examined an industrial Cu/ZnO/AlaOa catalyst under standard conditions; they concluded that methanol synthesis proceeded from carbon dioxide, and that the reverse water-gas shift reaction (which produces CO from COg) was slower than the synthesis reaction to give methanol. Chinchen et al. also note [4] that in a working methanol synthesis catalyst, CO can be expected to exchange oxygen rapidly on the copper surface. This fact gives rise to their supposition that the hydrogenation of a 'WO/^C^O mixture should produce some isotope scrambling in the methanol product. This oxygen exchange is in contrast to the performance of a supported rhodium catalyst, where no scrambling occurs. In Bart and Sneeden's review [5], both stepwise reduction of carbon oxides, as well as the possibility of initial CO reaction to COg and subsequent hydrogenation to methanol, are compared. It is pointed out that methanol is obtained predominantly from COg without the intermediate formation of CO. In many recent investigations [6-10], there is broad agreement concerning the fact that COg rather than CO is the precursor of methanol. Only very recently considerable doubts have been formulated concerning the genera- lization of these results to other catalysts systems. Jennings et al. [11, 12] have studied methanol synthesis catalysts derived from binary rare earth/ copper precursors and from ternary rare earth/Cu/Ti, Zr or Al precursors. Their results obtained with 14CO^ indicate that methanol is formed by hydrogenation of carbon monoxide; the mechanism therefore differs from that which is characteristic of conventional Cu/ZnO/AlgOs catalysts. Authors from the same research group have discussed two basic types of CO hy- drogenation mechanisms [13]. In reactions of type I, adsorbed CO is hy- drogenated while the C 0 bond remains intact, and a second C 0 bond is neither formed nor broken. Mechanisms of type II involve an intermediate with two C 0 bonds, typically surface formate. In the hydrogenation reaction producing methanol, one of the two oxygen atoms remains on the surface. For the rare earth/copper catalysts investigated in [13], both mechanisms appear possible to the authors. The identification of surface species on our metal/zirconia COg hydro- genation catalysts has been discussed in Part I of this study [14]. The production of methane was correlated with surface formate as a precursor, whereas ir-bonded formaldehyde and surface-bound methylate were found 245 to correlate with the production of gas phase methanol. In the present paper (Part II) the results obtained on copper/zirconia systems will be compared with those obtained in Part I for palladium/zirconia catalysts. From this comparison, the dependence of the product selectivities with respect to methanol and to methane on the metal (palladium or copper) will be discussed. Experimental Details of the apparatus and measurement techniques employed were described in Part I [14]. In the present study, three types of catalysts are investigated: (i) an amorphous copper/zirconia catalyst obtained by in situ activation of a rapidly quenched CuyoZrao alloy, as described in [15]; (ii) the catalyst denoted in the following as Cu (60 wt.%)/Zr02, prepared by coprecipitation of copper and zirconium hydroxides [16]; (iii) the catalyst identified as Cu (4 wt.%)/Zr02 obtained by sequential precipitation of zirconia and copper hydroxide [16]. Hydrogenation reactions over copper/zirconia catalysts In the following sections we shall present diffuse reflectance FTIR spectra that were recorded on the copper/zirconia catalysts described in the expe- rimental section. For convenience, the assignments of the observed absorptions to the relevant surface species, which have been identified in Part I of this study [14], are summarized in Table 1. Formate peaks were immediately observed during the first minute after the flow was switched on (Fig. 1). Later some methanol is formed, as observed by the weak peak at 1050 cm"1 and a broad absorption around 2900 cm"1 in the spectrum taken after 30 min. The latter peaks can be enhanced if the flow is stopped and the surface is exposed to the static reaction mixture at a total pressure of 3 bar. The diffuse reflectance FTIR spectrum was monitored as a function of time after the flow was switched from pure hydrogen to a COa/Hg (1:3) reaction mixture (bottom and middle traces), and after subsequent termination of the gas flow (p=2.5 bar, top trace). On regarding our findings for the copper/zirconia catalysts, the correlations observed for the hydrogenation reactions of COg and CO are seen to be very similar to those observed for zirconia-supported palladium. COg/Hg mixtures preferentially yield surface formate; the appearance of surface formaldehyde and methylate species can be correlated with the presence of gaseous carbon monoxide. It appears that the support plays an important role in providing adsorption sites for the relevant surface reaction intermediates, which are largely the same m the presence of either copper or palladium as the catalytically active metal. The metals, on the other hand, activate the adsorbed hydrogen for the catalytic reductions. The reactivity pattern of the activated hydrogen is different for the two metals, as evidenced by the different dynamics of surface species for the two types of systems. In palladium-catalyzed hydrogenations, surface formate appears as the direct precursor of methane. In contrast, on the copper catalysts formate does not participate significantly in the hydro- genation reaction at all. Conclusions With palladium/zirconia catalysts, methane as the predominant hydro- genation product is formed by hydrogenation of surface formate, which is derived from COg adsorption. Apparently the water-gas shift equilibrium (1) is biased towards COa on the palladium/zirconia catalysts. This could be due to the fact that the hydrogen released upon COg formation is dissociatively adsorbed on the palladium metal, and is subsequently consumed in methane formation.
